bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 11, 1900

div1.p: Reed writes about the possibility of Emilie Lawrence Reed coming to Cuba. He also describes the visit of the examining board from Havana, and records responses to the mosquito theory.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 11, 1900
div1.p:
Here
came a nice fat letter,
yesterday, from my darl-
ing girls and, also, a very
thin one from poor, sweet
“oomsey” dear- The first I
enjoyed so much, for it
told me that the sweet
sufferer was “feeling real
well”, but the other made
me real unhappy with
its news of another attack
of that horrid trouble
in my sweet farmer-lady's
ankle -- still I had to laugh
at your darling expression
about “feeling like a widow”-
Well, well! what has got
into your precious head
my sweet “oomsey”? “When
are you coming back”? &c,
you know that you didn't
expect me to come back
as soon as this, and just
as our observations are
proving so valuable, how
could you even think
of my returning and leav-
ing affairs at their most
important stage? Tut!
Tut! lovie, dear, don't for-
goodness sake, begins
to talk that way! Of course
I am just as anxious
to come as can be, and I
am looking forward with
perfect delight to the time when I can
come, but it won't be
before Christmas. Con-
cerning your coming, noth-
ing would delight me more
than to have you come down.
if I only had some place
for you to get your meals.
You couldn't mess with
us, as things are, at present,
for your precious nose
would curl up over
your forehead if you
saw our outlay- Dr Bisp-
ham leaves, next week,
to bring back a baltimore
girl, but I think that he
will hardly have her join
our bill of fare- I
C1
B9
could make you quite comfor-
table, otherwise, and nothing
would give me such pleas-
ure as to have my precious
wifie and daughter, too, to
come- But little joy must
not interrupt her studies.
How could she get along
without you? Who would
help her in her studies?
Who would look after
her and stay with her? Please
let me know all of these
things when you next write,
for I will see, if I can't ar-
range to have us board
with Dr Kean's Mess. Rest
assured that I will do every
thing to keep my sweet wifie
from feeling “like a widow”!
Consider every thing carefully
and let me know in your
next letter just what you
want to do and just what
you think that you can
do, remembering that
precious pink joy daughter
must be left in very safe
hands. I do know that you would
be delighted with the country
when you once get here-
Before I forget it, sweetheart,
as I can't go into town and
wouldn't know what to
get even if I did go go,
please take $20.00 & get you
some pretty Christmas pres-
ent and $10.00 for something
for our darling smart
and sweet little daughter.
Don't forget to do this-
And if you could get Beech-
ner something, too, I would
be very glad. He is
such a reliable & accommoda-
ting old fellow, that I want
to show him our apprecia-
tion of him. Our patient,
concerning whom I wrote
you in my last, is doing
very well- We had Dr John
Guiteras, Dr Finlay & Dr Alber-
tini here to see him, yester-
day afternoon- They were
all immensely interested
and Dr Albertini did not hes-
itate to say “Yellow Fever ”-
The others, too, regarded the
case as one of probable
yellow fever, but desired
to see how his temperature
& pulse would run during
the next two days. Dr Amador,
an expert in yellow fever, says
the disease is undoubtedly
yellow fever. Of course, I
can't blame any one from
witholding a diagnosis, until
they are satisfied, but it is
from my standpoint very
amusing. The case is as
clear plain as a nose on a man's
face, but has Dr Guiteras
has pronounced, in an
interview, our theory as
being “very wild and im-
probable”, of course, he
wants to be “let down easy”,
for he sees already that
he must surrender. He
will come around in a
few days- Dr Gorgas, also,
saw the patient, and pronounces
the case as so suspicious
that had it occurred in
Havana, he would not
have hesitated to send him
to the yellow Fever Hospital-
Ah! wonderful is nature,
and I thank God that he
has allowed poor, unwor-
thy me to look a little way
into this secret! Six months
ago, when we landed on
this Island, absolutely nothing
was known concerning the
propagation & spread of yel-
low Fever -- it was all an
unfathomable mystery --
but, to-day, the curtain has
been drawn -- its mode
of propagation established --
and we know that a case --
minus mosquitoes -- is no
more dangerous than one
of chills & fever! Hurrhah!
I will write to Dr Sternberg in a
few days about the case -- of
course, he will, at once, write
an article & say that for 20
years he has considered
the mosquito as the most
probable cause of yellow
fever- That would be just
in order for him to do so-
Dr Wasdin, of the marine
Hospital Service, has written
a very discourteous reply
to our preliminary note, in
the same Journal that our
article appeared in- As
soon as I can get time, I
shall pay him my compli-
ments in a style that he
will never forget! Dr
Cobb, of the same service,
has, also, written a very
courteous and interesting
answer to our paper, in
which he proves, to his own
satisfaction, that the mosqui
-to can't possibly propagate
the disease, & says that it
would be dreadful, after
all the years of disinfection
that his service has done,
if this theory should be what
we have claimed for it-
And so the ball rolls on!
Well, it is after ten o'clock
& I have written a long letter
to my sweet “oomsey”- So, with a
kiss & a hug, I will say, “good-night”
you sweet Miss Gouty! Boo! Boo!
Saturday Wednesday morning-12th- Wake up! you
precious, sweet girls and stop that ever-
lasting snoozing! Your old Mr Papa
is just preparing to take a cold shower-
bath- Don't you wish that you had
both had one? What lazy, sleepy girls!
nevertheless kisses & love for my sweet children.
